citeinfo.origin: U.S. Department of Commerce, Bureau of the Census
Massachusetts Institute for Social and Economic Research, University of Massachusetts
Massachusetts Office of Geographic and Environmental Information (MassGIS)
citeinfo.title: Massachusetts Railroad Stations, 1996

descript.abstract: This datalayer is a point coverage which displays Railroad Stations throughout the state of Massachusetts. This layer was derived from the Massachusetts Electronic Atlas database published by the Harvard Map Collection in 2001.The Massachusetts Electronic Atlas (MEA) was a collaborative project to provides access, via the Internet, to data about the Commonwealth, its thirteen regional planning agency districts and 351 cities and towns. This dataset is now only available via The Harvard Geospatial Library.These data were originally compiled by the Center for Transportation and Public Safety (CTPS) from data provided by the Executive Office of Transportation (EOTC), the MBTA, and individual railroad operators; then supplied to MassGIS to create their "TRAINS" datalayer. The ground condition reference date for this MassGIS layer is October, 1996. This file contains all the railroad stations for the entire state. Each station is given a CTPS id number. Unfortunately the name of the station is only provided for 95 of the 1307 stations. Additional names will be appended to this file as updates from CTPS are received.
descript.purpose: This layer is intended for researchers, students, and policy makers for reference and mapping purposes, and may be used for basic applications such as viewing, querying, and map output production. This layer will provide a basemap for layers related to socio-political anaylsis, statistical enumeration and analysis, or to support graphical overlays and analysis with other spatial data. More advanced user applications may focus on demographics, urban and rural land use planning, socio-economic analysis and related areas including defining boundaries, managing assets and facilities, integrating attribute databases with geographic features, spatial analysis, and presentation output.

place.placekt: United States Geological Survey (USGS) Geographic Names Information System (GNIS)

idinfo.useconst: For educational, non-commercial use only. Although this data set has been developed by the Harvard Map Collection and its partners, no warranty expressed or implied is made by the producers as to the accuracy of the data and related materials. The act of distribution shall not constitute any such warranty, and no responsibility is assumed by the producers in the use of this data, or related materials.

cntinfo.hours: Monday through Friday 9:00 A.M. to 4:00 P.M. EST-USA

idinfo.datacred: The Massachusetts Electronic Atlas dataset was a joint project of Douglas Carnahan, formerly of the Metropolitan Area Planning Council (MAPC), Richard Gelpke of the Earth and Geographic Sciences Department of the University of Massachusetts at Boston, and David Cobb, Bonnie Burns, Martin von Wyss, and Arlene Olivero of the Harvard Map Collection. Valuable technical assistance and support has been provided by Environmental Systems Research Institute (ESRI), Peter Girard of ESRI, and the Harvard College Library.
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows 2000 Version 5.0 (Build 2195) Service Pack 4; ESRI ArcCatalog 8.3.0.800

attracc.attraccr: Topological PropertiesThe attribute accuracy of these files is as precise as the source used during the creation or update of the Massachusetts Electronic Atlas (MEA) database. No specific field tests for attribute accuracy have been conducted on the files.

dataqual.complete: Data completeness of the Massachusetts Electronic Atlas (MEA) files reflects the contents of the database at the time the files were created. Data for a given category contain attribute codes that reflect the information portrayed on the original source.

horizpa.horizpar: The Massachusetts Electronic Atlas' (MEA) mission to profile the Commonwealth's people and institutions did not require the highest level of positional accuracy. Coordinates in these files are in decimal degrees and have six implied decimal places. The six-decimal place precision is useful when producing maps as it allows you to place features that are next to each other on the ground in the correct position, relative to each other, on the map without overlap.From MassGIS website documentation on tis Trains layer:"The linework is generally excellent, although some railroads are discontinuous (not perfectly edgematched) at USGS 1:100,000 quadrangle boundaries."<

citeinfo.origin: Massachusetts Executive Office of Environmental Affairs
citeinfo.title: MassGIS Trains Datalayer

srcinfo.srccontr: The Central Transportation Planning Staff updated and enhanced railroad linework distributed by the United States Geological Survey (USGS) as 1:100,000 Digital Line Graphs (DLGs). CTPS added several attributes pertaining to type of service, MBTA Commuter Rail status and stations, rail line ownership, and freight and passenger operation. MassGIS distributes these data as a single statewide coverage called TRAINS. In addition to the new attribute coding mentioned above (on Ownership, Source of data, etc.), some linework obtained from a variety of sourceswas added to the DLGs by CTPS staff. CTPS also created routes and sections from the arcs for the Commuter Rail lines. MassGIS performed quality checking on the data

citeinfo.origin: See Citation information for this datalayer
citeinfo.title: Massachusetts Electronic Atlas

srcinfo.srccontr: Rail line and Attribute tabular data

procstep.procdesc: Harvard Map Collection and MEA Project staff derived line and tabular data from MassGIS TRAINS datalayer.

cntinfo.hours: Monday through Friday 9:00 A.M. to 4:00 P.M. EST-USA

procstep.procdesc: The files were processed to shapefile format using the TGR2SHP.exe software program from GIS Tools (version 4.0). The shape file was then imported to an ArcSDE Layer.

cntinfo.hours: Monday through Friday 9:00 A.M. to 4:00 P.M. EST-USA

altsys.altenc: Explicit elevation coordinate included with horizontal coordinates

enttyp.enttypd: Points represent locatin of rail stations

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.
